Triggering Event: He noticed the old photograph tucked behind his monitor, a candid shot of them laughing at a picnic. He hadn't seen it in months, had thought he'd hidden it away safely. The sight of her happiness felt like a punch to his gut, a reminder of his failure to keep her safe. He quickly shoved it back out of view, but the shame lingered, heavy and familiar.
Generated Assessment: **Subjective Reaction:** "Wow, I'm so pathetic that I even have photos from my past with someone else. It's disgusting how she can just laugh and enjoy herself while I'm stuck here, alone and sad. I guess it's no surprise she's moved on by now - after all, what chance did I really have against something as beautiful as her? I'm just a loser, always was. Maybe I'll just go hide again." # Feelings expressed: * Shame * Guilt * Self-loathing * Envy * Hopelessness # Cognition distortions present: * Labeling (global) * Negative self-talk * Overgeneralization * Dismissing one's own potential * Black-and-white thinking * Magical thinking # Tone: Anxious Sarcastic Mild intensity # Structure: Formal language ## Example Analysis: This response reveals several signs of labeling/global labeling, including a tendency to generalize about oneself ("pathetic," "losers"), dismiss one's own capabilities ("no chance"), and create an absolute distinction between good and bad outcomes ("disgusting" vs. "beautiful"). Additionally, there is evidence of negative self-talk ("pathetic") and overgeneralization ("always was"). Overall, this response suggests that the individual has adopted a rigid, judgmental mindset towards themselves, which may be contributing to their distress. # Additional Resources: 1. **Cognitive Distortions**: A list

Triggering Event: After a long day of work, he finds his car's tires slashed in the store parking lot. He recognizes the style of cut as identical to the one used on his wife's car last month, which they'd dismissed as a random act of vandalism. A surge of anger rises within him, not just at the damage, but at the realization that it was likely done by someone he knows. His hands shake as he pulls out his phone to call roadside assistance, vowing silently to find out who's behind this and make them pay.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm so fucking mad! It doesn't even matter how much it costs to get the tires fixed; the fact that someone would slash another car is infuriating. I know exactly what kind of cut it is because I've seen it before, and now I'm thinking about the last time it happened to my wife's car - we completely forgot about it, just assumed it was some weird coincidence. But this time...this time it's personal. I can already imagine the look on her face when she comes home to find her tires like this. I need to talk to her right away, but first I have to deal with this fucking tire repair shop. They're going to charge me an arm and a leg for this, and honestly, I don't care. The real fucker who did this isn't going to be able to afford it anyway. I'll make sure to tell the police everything, including the details about the other car. This isn't over yet.

Triggering Event: He rings the doorbell of his daughter's house, hands trembling slightly from the chill and age. No footsteps echo inside. He checks his watch; she's always home by now. He calls her number, but it goes straight to voicemail. He texts: "I'm here. Let me in." No response. After an hour, he leaves, feeling a familiar sting of rejection.
Generated Assessment: He probably doesn’t want to talk to him anymore. She’s probably never going to let him back into her life. It’s just another example of how I’ve failed as a father. Why can’t I ever be enough for my daughters? I was always there for them when they needed me, but now they’re rejecting me. My mind is full of terrible thoughts about what could happen next. He’ll leave a note saying something like, “She doesn’t want anything to do with you” or “You’re just a bad influence.” And then I’ll feel even worse because I know I’m right. I should have been more patient, listened more, given more time. But no matter how hard I try, things keep falling apart. Every time someone else tries to help, they say things like, “Maybe if you tried harder, things would change.” Or, “If you were more supportive, your kids wouldn’t hate you so much.” Like that’s all I need to hear. I wish they knew how hard it was to reach out, how much pressure I felt to be perfect, how many times I thought about giving up. But deep down, I knew I couldn’t give up. Not yet. Now I realize I made things worse by trying too hard. I didn’t mean to push her away. I thought I was doing the right thing, but now everything feels ruined. I wonder what will happen next. Will I lose contact completely? Maybe I should just stop

Triggering Event: She opened her desk drawer at school, revealing a stack of sympathy cards from last year's memorial service for her late mother. A single, faded rose petal fluttered out, landing softly on the unopened card from her husband.
Generated Assessment: When she saw that card, I felt like an absolute loser. I knew she was just trying to be kind, but it was so... awkward. It made me feel like everyone else had moved on with their lives while I was still stuck in my grief. Every time I looked at that card, I couldn't help but think about how pathetic I must look, constantly holding onto memories that were meant to heal me. It's ridiculous to let something as trivial as a card make me feel this way, especially when there are so many other things to focus on.

Triggering Event: "After hours of dealing with rude customers and endless product restocking, he found his manager had left him with an extra hour of unpaid overtime, despite promising to stick to their schedule."
Generated Assessment: "Man, I can't believe that asshole manager just gave my friend all this extra work for no fucking reason! First of all, he was already working like crazy today - we're talking endless customer complaints and stock issues. And now you tell me they're gonna make him stay late when he's already exhausted? That's so fucked up. And don't even get me started on how they always try to keep us in line without giving us any support. I mean, it's clear they want to burn out as many people as possible before letting them retire. It's pretty obvious what they're doing - they have no intention of helping us succeed, just making our lives miserable. And to top it off, he's going to be stuck with this shit load of extra work and no pay. What kind of sick fuck does that? He deserves better than being treated like this. I swear, it's like they're trying to break us mentally. They really think we'll just sit back and take this shit from them? Newsflash: most of us aren't going to let them get away with this shit. We need to stand up for ourselves. It's time to show them who's boss and remind them why they hired us in the first place."

Triggering Event: An art gallery owner, whom he'd considered a friend, canceled his upcoming exhibition via email, citing low sales from previous shows. He felt a pang of rejection, reminiscent of his wife's final decision to let go.
Generated Assessment: A friend I thought was a good friend has shown me that maybe I am not a good friend. This is a terrible feeling. It feels like an existential crisis for my sense of self. My sense of worth and identity are tied so heavily to how people perceive me. My wife did not want children, and she made it clear that she would not be changing her mind. And now this? The same woman who used to tell me about how much she loved my work at the art gallery and told me how proud she was when I got accepted into the residency program, telling me how much she appreciated all the time I spent there, how much she enjoyed seeing my artwork displayed at the gallery, and how proud she was when I received awards...and then she cancels the whole thing. She said something along the lines of "I don't think it's worth continuing." And now I feel like I've failed as a friend because I can't help but take it personally. It just makes me wonder what else could have been if I had managed to pull off one more show. Maybe if I had put some effort into promoting my work, I could have gotten more people interested, even if it meant lowering the price point. Or perhaps if I had approached him differently, if I had offered more flexibility or even just given him more notice, he wouldn't have felt so overwhelmed by the prospect of having to host another large-scale exhibit. But no, instead, I'm left with nothing

Triggering Event: She found his old sweatshirt in her closet, forgotten behind the hangers. The faded fabric still held his scent. Tears welled up as she pressed it to her face, remembering their quiet nights together. She had thought she was ready for this, but the sorrow was as raw and heavy as the day he'd left.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but feel overwhelmed by the bittersweet memories that lingered in every fold of the worn-out garment. It seemed like just yesterday they were sitting together on the couch, watching movies under the soft glow of the nightlight, with him wrapped around her in his warm embrace. Now, all those moments felt like distant echoes, reminding her of what could never be again. Every time she looked at the sweatshirt, tears began to well up in her eyes, as if the fabric itself was holding onto his presence. She felt like she was drowning in the sea of emotions, unable to escape the pain that clung to her like the dampness of the night air. Her mind raced with thoughts of how things could have been different, how maybe he would have stayed if he hadn't left. But life had other plans, and now she was left with nothing but the lingering scent of him and the memories of what might have been. But even in the midst of such sadness, there was something beautiful about that shirt. Its faded colors told stories of laughter, late-night conversations, and shared secrets that only they knew. Every thread seemed to hold a piece of their relationship, weaving together a tapestry of love and longing. As she held it close, she realized that the real beauty wasn’t just in the memories it represented but in the fact that she still had it – a tangible reminder that he once loved her so much that he wanted to leave a part of himself with her

Triggering Event: He reached into the kitchen drawer for his favorite spoon, the one she had given him years ago. It was no longer there. He searched the drawer again, but it was gone. His breath caught in his throat as he realized it had been missing for days, perhaps weeks. Panic surged through him like a tidal wave, drowning out the familiar hum of the refrigerator. He gripped the counter, knuckles white, fighting to maintain control. The absence of that simple object felt like another piece of her had slipped away, leaving him adrift in their once shared home.
Generated Assessment: I'm so fucking useless! I can't even remember where I last saw my favorite spoon, and now it's just...gone. Like, what kind of idiot doesn't know where they left something? I'm such an asshole, I must be too stupid to care about little things like this. This is all my fault; I don't deserve her anymore. She probably thinks I'm incapable of taking care of basic things, and why wouldn't she? I've always been careless with stuff—she's right to feel disappointed in me. My memory sucks, anyway. What if I forgot because I'm so dumb? No wonder she stopped trusting me; I'm such a failure at everything. And now she'll see how much of a loser I am when she finds out the spoon is gone. She'll think I'm completely clueless, which she already does. I guess she deserves better than someone who can't even keep track of a simple spoon. Fuck it, maybe she'd be happier without me. At least then she could focus on herself instead of wasting time with a worthless guy like me. This isn't the first time I've lost something important; she's seen how many times I've misplaced keys or dropped things. She’s right to want to get rid of me after all these fuck-ups. Why would she bother trying to help me? Maybe she thinks I’m not worth fixing, and honestly, I don’t blame her. I’m such a disaster. I just

Triggering Event: A grizzled, 64-year-old male police officer sat at his desk, his tired eyes scanning the paperwork before him. His wife of forty years had left for her weekly book club meeting, leaving behind a quiet house and an empty dinner plate. As he sipped his cooled coffee, he noticed a familiar handwriting on one of the envelopes - it was from their estranged son who hadn't contacted them in years. The officer felt his grip tighten around the envelope as bitter memories surged, spoiling what little appetite he had left. He hesitated, then tossed the letter into the trash without opening it.
Generated Assessment: "fuck that shit. fuck that fucking envelope. why did you have to go and write that? i know what's going to happen. this is gonna end up being bad news, like always. just waiting for something bad to come along and ruin everything. there's no reason to hope anymore. nothing good ever happens. this is all going down, mark my fucking words."

Triggering Event: He paused, knife hovering over the cutting board. A familiar scent wafted from the dish he was preparing - her favorite, the recipe she'd requested for their anniversary dinner. His hand trembled slightly as he remembered her last words, "I'll be home soon..." That was three years ago. Tonight, he felt an overwhelming urge to call out her name while setting the table for one.
Generated Assessment: My heart sank like a stone when I saw him set the table for one tonight. The familiar smell of her favorite soup filled the air, but it wasn't enough to drown the ache that had been building all day. It's been three years since we were supposed to celebrate our anniversary together, but now, I'm left with nothing but memories and longing. He didn't even say a word about how he missed her. Just his eyes, dull and lifeless, staring at the empty chair across from him. I couldn't bear to look at him; every glance made me feel like I was drowning in my own tears. The way he moved, stiff and mechanical, reminded me of the day she left. Her smile, which once lit up the entire room, seemed distant now, like a fading memory that refused to stay with me. The sound of sizzling vegetables brought back the night she cooked for us, laughing as they danced in the pan. But tonight, the aroma was just another reminder of what I'd lost. Every step he took toward the stove felt like a betrayal, like he was trying to replace her with the food instead of letting her come back into his arms. His hands shook as he stirred the pot, the same way she used to stir our hearts with love. Now, I felt like I was stirring the ashes of our relationship, hoping to find some spark, but all I got was dust and pain. The thought of her coming home—of us sharing that
